The duration of the contraction has varied from 11 months following the first interest rate increase to as long as 86 months.
The Federal Reserve's aggressiveness in increasing interest rates has generally been decisive in the reaction of the economy and financial assets, though not always.
This is the reason why the US central bank officials should emphasize that investors should focus not on when interest rates will start rising, but on how long the normalization process will take.
It is a fact that there are various variables.
However, the result may be that the market participants think that the rate hike hysteria is exaggerated.

Julian Jessop, Global Chief Economist at Capital Economics, said in a note to clients, "It is inevitable that some will interpret the Fed's first rate rise since the global financial crisis as signalling the end of an era of cheap money."

On the contrary, we do not expect US interest rates to return to normal anytime soon, but it is seen that the majority of the currently low levels of interest rates is a seismic shock that has been feared.
Still, we cannot say that it will have no effects.
Based on past trends, the reaction that some sectors of the economy could give is as follows:
As we have seen in the past months, expecting interest rates to rise can unbalance some things for a while.
The effect is not so significant when the interest rate is increased.

In a new study on what will happen after rate hikes, Deutsche Bank analysts say, "It is seen that there is a trend of a 12-24 month pause in core earnings following the first rate hike, which could reflect the pause in monetary policy."

According to a recent analysis shared by Bob Doll, an analyst at Nuveen Asset Management, in Barron's the market usually registers sharp increases during the last 35 years - an average of around 14 percent - and then moves in a straight line towards the interest increase 250 days later - an average increase of 2.6 percent - and then returns to normal and provides an average return of 14.4 percent in the last six cycles.
Deutsche, said the effect on shares will become more pronounced at the later stages of the rate-hike cycle, with dividend yields disappearing.
Setbacks are a fact of economic life, but interest rate increases help them.
The Fed is currently faced with some conditions that did not exist previously and could hasten the decline.
The most striking thing is that the gross domestic product is at the lowest level so far for the Fed interest rate increase.
According to Deutsche Bank, out of the 118 interest rate increases seen since 1950, nominal year-on-year gross domestic product growth dropped below 4.5 percent only on two occasions.
Although growth has been recorded at 3.6% in the second quarter of 2015, according to the Atlanta Fed, few expect this to last and third quarter growth is projected at 1.5%.
According to Deutsche, raising interest rates in such a fragile economic environment could be risky, and could lead to the question "will it be different this time?"
The attention of market participants who have been waiting for the Fed to increase interest rates for a year is on the Federal Open Market Committee meeting, which will end on Thursday.
While most strategists and economists believe the FOMC could approve an increase at this meeting, futures trading is pointing to only a 25% chance.

The report states, "In all of our research since 1950, all of the expansion cycles occurred within the context of a super rising trend cycle, and the gross national product, after a slow recovery, is quickly approaching the highs reached before the recession."
On the contrary, this has been a recovery in the slowest pace of growth on record in a period of exemplary stability.
The current cycle is the longest since the Fed has waited since the last recession — the longest cycle on record was 35 months and the current cycle is 74 months and still ongoing.
The fixed income market has become unstable due to the expectation of the interest rate to increase and the structure somewhat resembles our own equity.
The real difference is that when Fed policy changes course, the effect is seen more quickly in bonds than it is in stocks.
When the first increase/decrease in the cycle occurs, bond yields do not immediately change direction.
At the end of the rate hike cycle, bond yields go down immediately," Deutsche said.
According to the strategists at Charles Schwab, rising interest rates will flatten the yield curve by narrowing the gap between the yields on longer-dated and shorter-dated bonds.

Kathy Jones, one of the analysts at Schwab says that in the analysis, high-yield bonds generally perform better in such an environment, but she also says "we are still cautious in terms of reaching the yield."
Intriguingly, Jones believes markets have already adapted to the Fed's policy expectations.
"In addition to the strength of the dollar and the decline in inflation expectations, there are various signs that the market is being organized according to a tighter monetary policy," he wrote.

Short-term interest rates are rising, the yield curve is flattening, credit spreads are widening, and volatility is increasing - all of the characteristics that will be observed in the market when the Fed tightens policy.
From a broad point of view, companies that do most of their business in the United States will profit when interest rates rise and local products become more attractive.
The situation of multinational companies with high debts will be worse, as the rising dollar will make products more expensive in the global market, and their debts will be more expensive.
Goldman Sachs analysts said in a report prepared for clients, "History shows that 'quality' stocks can experience underperformance at the start of such a rise".
Firms with strong balance sheets outperformed those with weak balance sheets by about 5 percent on average, following rate increases in 1994, 1999 and 2004.
Companies with high capital returns and low-volatility stocks also outperformed their low-quality rivals with an average of 4 to 3 percent.
The debt will become a big issue.
According to Goldman, companies with high levels of foreign currency debt are most at risk.
Apart from the pure stock game, it is expected that consumers will also benefit from the increasing dollar.
Although the experts have different views on how fast they can save, savers can also benefit from high gains.
Andrew Bingham said that the BBC Radio 3 Classic FM is a copy of it.
Conservative MP Andrew Bingham accused the station of "going downmarket."
He argued that the radio was increasingly becoming similar to its commercial rivals.
He also accused the BBC Music Awards of targeting and undermining the Brit Awards.
His colleague, Damien Collins, accused The Voice of being unoriginal.
A prominent MP has pressured the broadcaster to reveal the difference between it and other commercial stations by saying that BBC Radio 3 is increasingly turning towards Classic FM.
Conservative MP Andrew Bingham also told BBC bosses the public service radio station was "going downmarket" and was becoming increasingly similar to its commercial rivals.
He said, "I don't like to use this term, but Radio 3 is becoming 'popularized' and is turning into a classic FM station."
In addition, it also targeted the BBC Music Awards, which was held last December.
The BBC Music Awards, which were launched last year, is essentially another version of the Brit Awards.
"If you're trying to do something different, those are the first two things that come to mind, and you just try to copy what's already out there," Bingham said.
The BBC's director general rejected the allegations and defended BBC Radio 3 as being far ahead of its commercial rivals in both live music and public education.
If I am learning something about classical music from Radio 3, I will not go and learn about it from somewhere else.
And this is the attachment to live music, and playing music is unlike anything else.
He also mentioned that he thinks it is very important that Radio 3 try to discover new music and introduce its work.

BBC Radio 3 controller Alan Davey claimed at the start of the year that the station needed to work harder than it had in the past to reach a wider audience, because Britons are less educated in the field of classical music.
However, Radio 3 was not the only element that was under fire at the Culture, Media and Sport Select Committee meeting because it is accused of stepping on the toes of its commercial rivals.
Tory MP Damien Collins also lashed out at The Voice, the BBC's music talent show, which it bought from Dutch production company Talpa Media for £22 million.
Can you not see why the program got so much attention, because it is not original and there is no special difference?
Lord Hall insisted the BBC1 show, which is judged by Paloma Faith and Boy George, was made in a "distinctly BBC style".
He said the organization should find its own hit before trying another entertainment program.
However, he did not accept the idea of preventing more production of O Ses in the future or that the money spent for the license fee should be spent on other formats.
Is Black Friday the reason why August saw the lowest growth in online sales in history?
In the first three months of 2015, there was a 7% increase in internet sales.
Last month, the lowest growth was recorded since 2000, when records began to be broken.
Three years ago, when mobile devices began to be used for shopping, there was an explosion in internet sales.
Experts say that Black Friday in November could be the reason for the drop in spending.
Online shopping has been booming for more than a decade, turning some of Britain's liveliest shopping streets into ghost towns.
After numbers showed that in the first three months of 2015, there was only a 7% increase in internet sales, experts pointed out that internet sales are increasingly showing signs of weakness.
In August, total spending only increased by five percent compared to the previous year, and the lowest growth was seen since the year 2000 when records began to be broken.
After figures show that internet sales experienced only a one percent increase during the first three months of 2015, experts point out that internet sales are increasingly showing signs of weakness.

IMRG sales index editor Andy Mulcahy told the Guardian, "If you look at the growth levels from previous years and particularly from 2000, you actually see that everything has returned to normal over time".
He also noted that Internet sales have experienced a great increase three years ago, when consumers started using their cell phones to purchase products.
This meant that more people could shop while lounging on the sofa.
But right now it's flat, you can see the decline.
The Black Friday phenomenon, imported from America, is cited as one of the reasons for the slowdown in sales.
The experts point out that consumers may be waiting for this event, which takes place on the last Friday of November, to buy something.
Last year's event saw five times more consumers storm company websites to grab cheap items than the previous year, causing many sites to crash.
Experts say that Black Friday may have 'tamed' shoppers for now, as footage showed customers fighting over bargains
A study conducted by the British Retail Consortium revealed that for every five pounds spent on shopping, one pound is spent on buying goods from the internet.
One third of some products, such as televisions and washing machines, are now purchased from Internet stores.
In addition, more than a quarter of the people buy their clothes and shoes from the internet rather than from luxury and glamorous shopping streets.
Muslims bid farewell to those who lost their lives in the crane accident in Mecca after the Bin Laden family have been found guilty
After the first funerals were held in Mecca, the remains of the 29 people who lost their lives were carried through the streets by Muslims.
Saudi Arabia holds the construction giant Saudi Binladin group responsible for the crane accident.
The Health Ministry reported that a total of 394 people were also injured after the collapse.
Hundreds of Muslims gathered to carry the bodies of 29 people who lost their lives when a crane collapsed at Mecca's Grand Mosque.
The large majority of the crowd, which was mostly white, blocked the roads to accompany the dead on their final journey to their last resting place at Muaysım cemetery in Mecca.
The distressed crowd passed through the holy site where the tragedy took place several days ago when the roof of a neighboring mosque collapsed and fell on the pilgrims.
After Saudi Arabia's Binladin construction holding was blamed for the incident, which also saw 394 people injured, the dead were brought back for burial.
The bodies of 29 pilgrims who lost their lives when a crane fell on the Grand Mosque were carried on shoulders along the route.
Among the dead was Kasim Akram, a father of four from the Bolton area of Manchester, who was on his first pilgrimage.
Mr Akram came to Masjid al-Haram with his mother and father at the beginning of the annual pilgrimage.
Saudi leaders announced that the pilgrimage will continue with the participation of thousands of pilgrims on the way to Mecca.
In a statement today, King Salman said that the Binladin Holding group should not leave the crane's arm open when it is out of use.
According to the Arabic version of the decree prepared by the Saudi Press Agency, which is run by the government, there is only one party to be blamed for the incident, the Binladin Group.
The English service of the news agency did not report on this detail, but the company officials were informed that a travel ban had been imposed on them.

On Monday, Salman pledged to find the cause of the crane collapse in the courtyard of the Grand Mosque in Mecca, where hundreds of thousands of Muslims gathered for this month's annual Hajj pilgrimage.
The Binladin Group did not make any statement about the collapsed crane, and representatives were not allowed to make comments.
The royal decree accused the group of failing to take current security measures and failing to cooperate with meteorology authorities.
Dozens of cranes surround the holy mosque in Mecca, and most of the construction is managed by the Binladin group.
The Binladin family has been in close relations with the ruling family of Saudi Arabia for decades and is behind most of the construction projects.
Al-Qaeda's last leader, Osama bin Laden, was also a rebellious son who was disowned by the family.

The crash, which took place just days before millions of people converge on the Hajj pilgrimage area, where adult Muslims are required to visit at least once in their lives, came amid strong winds and heavy rain.
Officials said that 158 people were still being treated in hospitals.
Authorities have ordered compensation of 1 million riyals (£174,000) to be paid to the families of the dead and those who survived with permanent disabilities.
The other wounded will receive half of this amount.
The head of B&Q said that this trend is due to cheap Eastern European craftsmen.
Veronique Laury says that the British are increasingly hiring craftsmen.
Behind this increase is the number of East European master craftsmen.
As a result, 200 new Screwfix stores are being opened targeting tradesmen.
At the same time, Kingfisher is shutting down 60 B&Q stores across the country.
Written by: Rupert Steiner, Daily Mail City Editor
It is said that the British began to hire skilled East European craftsmen to do the work in their houses instead of doing it themselves with hammers and paint brushes.
If you are good at using a hammer or painting the walls, you are in the minority these days.
Because according to the boss of the company behind B&Q, Britons are increasingly hiring professionals to do DIY jobs in their homes.

Veronique Laury, the new chief executive of the home improvement chain Kingfisher, said the reason for the trend is a huge increase in the number of skilled Eastern European tradesmen offering services at low prices.
As a result, Kingfisher is closing 60 B&Q stores while planning to open 200 more Screwfix stores aimed at tradesmen.
Ms Laury wants more women to be employed in B&Q stores because she said eight out of ten purchase decisions were made by women.
Currently, the majority of the staff is male.
The growing demographic trends point to the need for a single woman homeowner to do more to improve their homes than in the past.
Mrs. Laury said, "There are still a lot of men working in our stores.
We need to create more balance.
Basically, half of our customers are women and 80 percent of the purchasing decisions are made by women.
Women play a big role in the decision making process.

Ms. Laury, one of the five women at the head of Britain's leading companies index FTSE100, has restructured her top management team so that it is comprised of an equal number of male and female directors.
With a staff of 50 percent women, including its CEO and its CFO, Kingfisher is practically alone in this field.
Ms Laury said: 'It was a conscious decision - diversity is an important issue here.
It was not hard to find good women to join our management team.
Kingfisher announced that after taking on the cost of closing the stores, there was a fall both in underlying profit and sales.
As a result of this trend, Kingfisher, which owns Screwfix and B&Q, plans to open 200 new stores.
It is time for the Federal Reserve to increase interest rates.

The Federal Reserve Bank's two-day meeting, which will continue on Wednesday and Thursday, is being watched closely by the whole world; the decision about whether or not to raise interest rates after a decade is expected.

In a Reuters poll, more than half of the 80 economists predicted that the Fed would implement this decision last week, while now they think that they will postpone this decision and hold the rates between 0% and 0.25%.
This is a historical event, since it has been seven years since the FED lowered the rates to zero.

Angel Ubide, a senior researcher at the Peterson Institute for International Economics, said: "For the first time, we are going to see a major central bank embark on a process of normalization of interest rates away from zero."
The United States economy is performing relatively well and adding trillions of dollars to the balance sheets in the process of reviving the economy and creating a small amount of inflation.
However, the FED cannot ignore the less optimistic global picture.
The markets were warned against any increase, but there were indications that the situation does not allow for such an increase.
The decision will be announced on Thursday at 8 pm.
The perpetrator of the murder at Delta State University left behind an apology letter.

According to officials, on Tuesday, Shannon Lamb, after shooting his girlfriend dead in Mississippi Monday morning and before killing a colleague later that day, left a note saying he was "sorry" for the first murder and wished he could "take it back."
The Gautier, Mississippi police reported that Lamb called 911 around 10:00 am.
On Monday, he indicated that he had killed someone by firing a gun.
Lamb told the operator on the phone that he had to send the police.
Lamb said he also had a "sweet dog" at home that does no harm to anyone, and is likely "very sad."
Although the police asked the caller his name, he did not specify his name.
Lamb made no comment about the murder.
When the police arrived at the scene, they found the body of Amy Prentiss, age 41, and a note written by Lamb, age 45: "I'm very sorry, I wish I could turn back time.
I loved Amy, and she was the only person who ever loved me.
Lamb, after writing the note, drove to Delta State 300 miles away and killed history professor Ethan Schmidt, then killed himself when police surrounded him.
University Dean William LaForge said he did not know of any problem between Lamb and Schmidt but "it was clear that there were things on Lamb's mind."

In a report released on Monday, Lamb believed that his girlfriend Prentiss was in an emotional relationship with Schmidt, but on Tuesday the officials said that there was "no information or evidence" of a "love triangle".
Shawn O'Steen, who was married to Prentiss for about seven years, describes Prentiss as a "good guy."
The couple divorced 15 years ago, but their friendship has continued.
O'Steen said Prentiss has a 19-year-old daughter and that the girl is "devastated."
O'Steen also noted that Prentiss and her daughter are "definitely best friends."
According to Lindsay Knowless, who the Sun Herald described as a close friend of Prentiss, Prentiss was working from home over the Internet.
Knowles said Prentiss, who owns a hunting dog named Lightning, has been with Lamb for about three years.
Knowles said he "always loved to help people."
Police said Lamb called his relatives on Monday and said he would not go to prison.
Later that evening, as police approached his vehicle on Highway 1 near Greenville, Lamb steered his car off the road and ran into a wooded area, where he shot himself and died.
According to his CV, published on the university's website, Lamb received his PhD in education from Delta State University in the spring of 2015.
Stars that have lost their former charm
The actor, seen with his son Redmond (right), has been through some very stressful years.
He fought leukemia in 2001, and in 2009 he lost his life partner Farrah Fawcett to cancer.
The actor, who is also said to have fought against drugs, was arrested in 2008 for possession of drugs.
All of this, of course, did him a lot of harm.
Manchester United's Luke Shaw will be out for months with a double fracture
Luke Shaw suffered two broken bones in his right leg in Manchester United's Champions League defeat to PSV Eindhoven.
This incident, which brought tears to the defender's eyes, will keep him off the field for at least six months, but Louis van Gaal remains hopeful that Shaw will return to the field this season.
The fracture was caused by a reckless challenge from Héctor Moreno in the 15th minute of the match, in which 20-year-old Shaw fell to the pitch like a bomb.
He was on the field for nine minutes and needed oxygen before being taken to the hospital.
Van Gaal said: "He has a double fracture and is now in the hospital."
Today or maybe tomorrow, he will be taken to Manchester and operated on.

It's a terrible situation - a young man transferred to Manchester at the age of 18,
he goes through a difficult time, then he plays brilliantly and then this happens.
He had an oxygen mask on his face in the locker room.
She was crying.
I am not a doctor, but if you have a double fracture, that means at least six months and it means you can't play in the group stage.
I hope to be able to play again this season.
Moreno was fortunate to escape with a red card and a penalty.
The referee, Nicola Rizzoli, did not punish the Mexican.
Van Gaal claimed that the Italian official had made a mistake.
You may judge yourself when I say that it was a penalty and a red card.
It was a very bad fight with two legs.
The tweet from Shaw's account said: "Thank you for all the messages, words can't describe how devastated I am, my road to recovery starts now, I will come back stronger."
Related: Manchester United in shock following Luke Shaw injury suffered in PSV defeat
This will be a morale boost for the English defender ahead of the Champions League final taking place in France next July.
PSV manager Phillip Cocu said: "It is a very bad injury."
Everyone is saddened when such an injury occurs to any player.
The intention of our players is never to injure an opponent.
Moreno had broken his leg while playing for Mexico against Van Gaal's Netherlands in the 2014 World Cup.
Cocu said he found the situation very difficult because his intention was never to injure an opponent and he did not feel good at all after hearing that it was a very bad break.
From my perspective, it was not possible to see that moment.
The only thing I could see was the ball going in different directions. It seemed as if Moreno had touched it, but I could not see Luke's shot.
In a statement from SBS 6, Moreno said: I know what it feels like. I know how difficult it can be.
I feel very bad and very sorry about this.
PSV's Andrés Guardado was taken to the hospital after a fight with Chris Smalling.
Surely David Cameron knows The Lorax better than that?
This is something every parent learns quickly: when your child loves a book, you know it won't take long to memorize it almost by heart.
It seems if you are not David Cameron.
When asked by a holiday planner for childcare suppliers what his favourite children's book was, the Prime Minister chose The Lorax, Dr. Seuss' 1971 environmental fable.

In a message published on the web site of SuperCamps Ltd., Cameron says: "I love reading it to my children because it has a funny, moving, creative and powerful message and there is always an image or a message that we miss in its content."

Up to this point, everything was going fine, until Cameron supposedly wrote something about the book's content, but in fact added new characters and details in order to inflate the original fairy tale text's content, in the book's 2012 film version summarized in the following paragraph.

In the walled city of Thneed-Ville, where all nature has vanished and even the air is a commodity, a boy named Ted wants to fulfill the wish of the girl of his dreams, Audrey, to see a real tree, writes a love story which includes a fairy tale that Dr. Seuss, whose real name is Theodor Seuss Geisel, who died in 1991, did not know.

If that's not enough to raise suspicion, the text of the script that Cameron put forward bears some striking similarities with a short synopsis of The Lora film on the Internet Film Archive, which begins: "In the walled city of Thneed-Ville where everything is artificial and even the air is a commodity, a boy named Ted wants to win the heart of Audrey, the girl of his dreams."

If we consider the claims that Cameron is a competent parent, it is highly unlikely that he is unaware of the main theme of the book in which a young boy, who is never named, hears how his local environment has been destroyed by greedy Once-lers, who cut trees, despite the objections of the Lorax, a short, bearded creature who "speaks for the trees".
Most probably, such a weak public relations work has been passed on to an employee, who apparently has not read The Lorax to a child 20 times in a row.
One of the presidential spokespersons indicated that the text was thought to have come from Cameron's election office.
SuperCamps confirmed that the text was supplied by Cameron's staff, but declined to comment further.
Adam Lyth was clearly under pressure, but he remained rock solid.

Playing against Pakistan in the United Arab Emirates is a difficult challenge, but after seeing the English team selected for the tour, I do not think there will be a repetition of the 3-0 Test series defeat we witnessed last time.
Still, I do not rule out the possibility of an away win.

Alastair Cook's team may be more inexperienced than the one three years ago, but they have good players in form and a strong collective ethos; that will not heal the wounds of 2012, but it will bring a little youthful optimism.
With the ball, Moeen Ali is developing into a game changer and Adil Rashid, while unproven at Test level, represents an attacking option.
Related: Adam Lyth dropped from England Test squad and replaced by Alex Hales
The decision to drop Adam Lyth is a difficult one for me to analyse as Head Coach at Yorkshire.
The Seven Tests were against two good attacks in trying conditions, and the simple but inescapable truth is that cricketers are judged on results.
For example, there was no doubt about Joe Root, the announcement had to be made because - as I said earlier - the players were their own best selection.
After a few fifties, Lyth could have seen his career extended, but he determined his own fate.
I hope that if he works harder for Yorkshire, he will get another opportunity.
England coach Trevor Bayliss praised the player's attitude, which didn't surprise me; above all, he is a team man.
It is difficult to answer this question of how long it would take for a Test cricketer to take notice.
Lyth - like Sam Robson before him - took seven catches, while Nick Compton managed nine.
Compton only got the chance to participate in the rematch.
The only pain you might feel for Jonathan Trott is that England went to the West Indies first - with Lyth in such form - but that was a wasted opportunity that is now in the past.
Alex Hales is coming and I think he's a high class batter.
We saw an X-factor cricketer and we saw this at the start of the season when he made 236 against us at Trent Bridge.
At the very least, it should be taken for the same opportunity but that of course depends on the team formation in the United Arab Emirates.
Moeen's idea of opening the batting alongside Cook to give him the chance to take four quick wickets worked, and I can't argue with that.
I don't understand why a batsman could not hit here, and this left-handed batsman already showed how good he was as a cricketer.
Moeen could have made the job for Worcestershire, but he saw a number 3 for them and it was not much of a difference.
My old team-mate, Justin Langer, played his first 38 Tests before his initial fall in 2001.
He took three hundred-lira banknotes and left without looking back.
Zafar Ansari returns to the team as a reserve spin bowler, and in the limited conversations I had with him he impressed me as a remarkable young man.

People can look at his raw statistics - 31 batting average, 35 on-base - and think of it as a decline, but there are not many game-changers who can raise their hands and the selection of players is young.
You will learn a lot on this tour.
Away from the team, it appears that England has made a few shrewd additions to its own coaching staff.
Appointing Sri Lanka batsman Mahela Jayawardene as a consultant for the Test matches may be an astute move.
He is one of the nicest guys in the game and will bring with him a wealth of experience gained in all sorts of conditions and against all kinds of attacks.
Paul Collingwood comes in for the white ball leg of the tour and adds both energy and ruthless efficiency to the batting order.
I've always felt he was born to be a part of the international cricket world, whether as a player or a coach, and he has a philosophy that can be emulated, like Mahela.
Sometimes new voices in the dressing room, even if they repeat the messages that have been said before, can bring a newness to the team.
Colly's Durham team mate Ben Stokes is rested for the one-day games, Root was given a similar break against Australia and I have no problem with that.
While everyone does not agree, the selection of plans, coaches and players is not done by those who select them.
And remember that, like the players, they are judged on results.
Such decisions are never made easily.
If the economy remains stagnant until 2017, the Brexit camp could win.

David Cameron's half-baked strategy for keeping Britain in the EU is going from bad to worse and that is despite Jeremy Corbyn's election as Labour leader and the TUC's meltdown over Europe on Tuesday.
There are also Corbyns and Nigel Farages among foreigners.

Recently a European diplomat friend of mine pointed out that some member states, who are now stuck with various crises in the EU for which they had no responsibility at all, are tired of Britain's self-serving, divisive privileges and obstructive treaty changes.
The TUC decided at its annual gathering in Brighton that it did not want these changes if they damaged social protection.
In fact, we could call it Dave and George's own agenda.

The prime minister and the deputy prime minister attend summits or bilateral meetings in the capitals of foreign countries, take their pictures in front of the famous monuments there, with or without the prominent people of that country, then return to their own country and say that they gathered allies for reform.
This is completely up to me.

While Berlin was saying "Don't leave us alone with France", my European friend who wanted an outward-looking Britain within the EU said that some increasingly short-sighted ministers and officials in certain capitals had reached the point of no longer caring whether we stay or go.

Germany's cautious and level-headed chancellor, Angela Merkel, is an ally and has been in office for 10 years, and as in the examples of Thatcher (11 years), Mitterrand (14) and Kohl (16), she wants to leave office before things turn bad.
François Hollande faces reelection in France in 2017, or a change of government.
It is also a fading power.
Soon, a nationalist government from the right wing will come to power in Poland, and a government from the left wing will come to power in Spain.
It is not very likely that Selfie will use its energy to prevent Scotland from leaving the United Kingdom, for this is not what the British want, for most of them have separatist tendencies.

So, some of these ministers, like the Scottish National Party, may have intentions of speeding up the Brexit process by making deliberate statements, which would not benefit this situation, in a similar way to the 2017 referendum campaign, as my friend says.
"Renegotiation was a dead end" and "Britain gained nothing from renegotiation."

Europeans remember from the previous experience how exploitative Fleet Street was, and how hostile to the European Union the oligarchic press barons were, for they were not like this in the time of Tony Benn, and they inspired the 2:1 referendum in 1975 which approved our entry in 1973.
People will remember, more or less, Boris Johnson, the former Brussels correspondent, who gained a reputation as the top Euro-opportunist in the early 1990s.
Despite all his idiocy, Ed Miliband knew who his enemies were.
Among these are tax evaders, illegal phone tappers and expatriates who own a large portion of our newspapers.

In fact, Tony Blair also thought pretty much the same things about them; however, as he was locked in a cage with a wild gorilla, he realized that in order to distract the gorilla from eating him for lunch and afternoon tea, he had to give him some bananas.

Actually, Miliband was more Blairite than Blair when it came to opposing Cameron's bright idea for a referendum, since Blair had compromised the principle of the EU constitution by giving an opt out to the French and the Dutch who voted on it in 2005.
The press did not forgive him on this issue either.

But on Monday, Jeremy Corbyn, who had been patting my back amiably in Westminster and saying he had no time to waste on me now, seemed to be in danger of reverting to the 80s Murdoch boycott strategy, which was a mistake then and is a mistake now.
It will take time, but he needs to develop a consistent strategy for communicating with the media, especially with Andrew Marr, who resigned from the BBC on Sunday.
I am describing Corbyn's official position in Europe as evolving.
He says that he wants the country to remain in a reformed EU.
Most people outside Ukip's hostile tendency, plus the ardent supporters of Little England Conservatism, would say yes.

Indeed, this was also what Hilary Benn, who is "a Benn but not Bennite", said this week on radio and TV, as he tried hard not to admit that it was a bad idea for Corbyn to appoint John McDonnell as his shadow chancellor.
This reminded me of my father's struggle in the 70s over the issue of loyalty to his colleagues in the cabinet, who did not go too far and lost his position in the cabinet.
Hilary's struggle was more captivating.
But, in Benn's phrase, ‘fighting to remain in all circumstances' was not the same as what McDonnell was saying or as what JC said to peers and MPs at the special meeting on Monday night.

And taking into account that he touched me, Corbyn also indicated that despite the preconceptions, the message discipline is still important in the 24/7 TV era, and particularly in the vortex of social media, which is a bed of paranoia and betrayal.
As McDonnell says, it is perfectly reasonable for Cameron to make sure that he has Labour's support on the referendum in order to avoid any difficulties on the issue of Europe.
Simon Jenkins definitely thinks so.

However, McDonnell and Corbyn's attempts to square Bennite siege economy and their anti-capitalist backgrounds with their pro-EU membership are no longer a matter of a specific debate among left-wing dissidents, who are just the basic stones of pedagogical tirades of small differences narsisism.
Foreign diplomats will have to struggle to draw meaning from all of these - as they did in his off-hand remarks about NATO - while Tom Watson is resolute that JC will make no campaign for leaving.
Why should Paris or Berlin, with sceptical voters of their own, risk political capital by granting Britain concessions that may all come to nothing?

As I was told at the opening of the British Influence Security Forum on Monday, the Americans are already very disappointed by the weak minimum performance of the British in Iraq, Libya and Syria, even with the cost-cutting Conservative Party government in power.
Experts criticise the UK Public Health e-cigarette research
Researchers have said that e-cigarettes are 95 percent less harmful than smoking at a 12-person meeting that included people with ties to the tobacco industry and was funded by a government agency.
Experts writing in the British Medical Journal (BMJ) have joined the Lancet in criticising the evidence used in a Public Health England (PHE) report on e-cigarettes.
PHE published its "landmark" report last month, which it described as a "thorough examination of the evidence".
But some researchers questioned the reliability of the data and pointed to ties between some experts and the tobacco industry.
An editorial in last month's Lancet medical journal took aim at what it called the "extraordinarily flimsy basis" of PHE's main conclusion.
Two other researchers writing in the BMJ questioned whether the claims were built on sand or rock.

Martin McKee, professor of European public health at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, and Simon Capewell, professor of clinical epidemiology at the University of Liverpool, said: "The fundamental principle of public health is that policies should be based on evidence of effectiveness."
They said they would expect PHE's claims that e-cigarettes were "around 95% less harmful than smoking" to be based on a detailed examination of the evidence and modelling.

Actually this is the result of a 12-person meeting assembled to develop a multi-criteria decision analysis (MCDA) model to form the synthesis of their views on the harms of these various nicotine-containing products; the results of the meeting have been summarized in a research article.

McKee and Capewell say that one of the sponsors of the meeting was a company called EuroSwiss Health, whose general manager had previously received funding from British American Tobacco for an independent research project.
They also said they approved the company's public health promotion certificate in a sustainability report.

They said that one of the 12 people at the meeting received funding from an e-cigarette manufacturer, but that it was not the same funding that was previously disclosed from the cigarette company Philip Morris International.
No information was given on how the panel members were chosen, but some of them reported industry funding in the article, including some of the known giants of e-cigarettes.
Some other people present at the meeting are not known for their expertise in tobacco control.
A representative from PHE's Tobacco Control Unit attended the meeting.
McKee and Capewell acknowledge that the research paper the group has written lacks "convincing evidence of harm on many criteria for most products".
However, none of these connections or restrictions are discussed in the PHE report.
MCKee and Capewell said the claim that there is no evidence that e-cigarettes are a stepping stone to smoking for children or non-smokers is premature.
Prof Kevin Fenton, the director of health and wellbeing at PHE, said the claims in the BMJ had been addressed previously.
He said: "e-cigarettes are considerably less harmful than smoking."
One out of two lifelong smokers die from their addiction.
All the evidence points to the fact that the health risks caused by e-cigarettes are comparatively small, but we should continue to investigate their long-term effects.
PHE has a clear mission: to inform the public, especially at a time of great confusion about the relative harms of tobacco, about what the evidence does and does not show.
About 80,000 people die each year from smoking-related illness and smoking costs the NHS £2 billion a year.
By clearly laying out the existing evidence - that e-cigarettes are not risk-free, but carry only a fraction of the harm caused by smoking - we are fulfilling our national responsibility.
Former Channel 4 boss says BBC should drop EastEnders

The former Channel 4 chairman Luke Johnson, who said the BBC should drop popular shows such as EastEnders and The Voice, suggested that commercial rivals would be "willing to pay good money" for hits like Albert Square dramas.
Johnson said the license fee should be used only to make programmes of a kind that other British broadcasters would not make.

The BBC has been criticized for broadcasting public service programs on channels like BBC4, with a smaller chance of being seen by a smaller group of viewers, instead of against competitors' most popular programs at regular intervals.

After the BBC's general director Tony Hall said the corporation wanted to work more closely with other organizations, Johnson said he'd tried to forge a link with the BBC during his time at Channel 4, but it had been unsuccessful for six years.

Johnson told the House of Lords communications committee that he is fighting the idea that the BBC should commission and broadcast programmes that are clearly suitable for showing by subscription-only rivals, during a questioning on the future of the BBC.
If you continue with the license fee, which I am not sure is a good idea in the medium or long term, it should be reduced at least to programs that others do not produce or order.
They broadcast The Voice in primetime because they want to draw as much support as possible for the future.
The main idea here is based on the notion that no one else will publish it, which is absurd and obviously nonsense.
Johnson said, "I don't understand why programs that can be funded without aid should be funded with a decreasing proportional tax.
The Voice is one of them and EastEnders is another and it is actually being done within the company.
To be honest, the other channels would give their right arms for this.
I am trying to see what public service broadcasts are like.
I do not think that this would diminish the BBC at all.

Johnson, who ran Channel 4 between 2004 and 2010, accused the BBC of chasing ratings because of "the passion of the people who work here and their view that this approach is the best way to guarantee long-term support."

The comments about the BBC's most popular programmes echo the views of former Sky executive Tony Ball, who used his 2003 MacTaggart lecture in Edinburgh to suggest that the BBC should sell programmes like EastEnders.

Johnson told the BBC that more suitable public service programs were moving to BBC4, where audience measurement was not possible, but they were being paid for by taxes, and they continued to contend with the pretentious piety tasks related to the 4 billion pounds in license fee revenue, and he added, "We are also, of course, making all these insipid programs that no one watches".
They put them into empty spaces where nobody is ever going to see them.
Regarding the license fee, Johnson told the committee: "I invite you to find a system that is more regressive from the point of view of those who will benefit best from it."

Of course you're thinking that, we're all thinking that, 150 pounds a year is a very good value, but I wonder if the reason that people who think that 150 pounds is a very big sum do not watch the BBC as much.
David Elstein, the former head of Sky and Channel 5 who also gave evidence to the committee on Tuesday, said the BBC needs to revise its Reithian mission to "inform, educate and entertain".

He said that some of the BBC's output is now officially classified as education, with one percent of its TV output and 0.1 percent of its radio output, and that Australian and Canadian public service broadcasters should lead the way and this should be changed to "inform, enlighten and educate".

On the subject of partnerships, Elstein said that the BBC should do something on the matter of proms, which are shown on TV in only a handful, and should enter into partnerships with advertisers to make all of them available to be watched online.
"Sonogenetics" enables brain cells to be controlled by sound waves.
In the video, it is seen how the spiders change direction when they are hit with the sound vibrations.
Scientists have raised crickets with genetically altered nervous systems that can be controlled by bursts of sound waves.
The tiny thread worms change direction when they are struck by high-frequency sound waves that humans cannot hear.
They are run by genetic modification, in which motor nerve cells have been genetically altered to carry ion channels that respond to ultrasonic vibrations.
Related: Researchers can read and write brain activity with light
Researchers say they have demonstrated the power of a new procedure called sonogenetics, which allows ultrasound to activate a series of brain, heart or muscle cells from outside the body.

Sreekanth Chalasani, a researcher at the Salk Institute in La Jolla, California, told the Guardian that one day this procedure could replace deep brain stimulation, an invasive procedure that involves putting electrical pulses into people's brains to treat Parkinson's disease symptoms.
Threadworms generally do not respond to sounds, but Chalasani found that they reacted when they were surrounded by a liquid containing microscopic bubbles.
The bubble he discovered strengthens the sound waves and allows them to pass through the mites.
The enhanced ultrasound waves are affecting structures called TRP-4 ion channels, which are found in membranes of some nematode cells.
According to a report published in Nature Communications, sound waves cause these ion channels to open and activate the cells to which they are connected.
To create worms that are controlled with sound, Chalasani genetically modified the worms so that some of their motor neurons carry TRP-4 ion channels.
When ultrasonic sound was applied to the modified creatures, sound waves were amplified by micro-bubbles and transmitted into the worms, where they activated altered motor neurons.
This procedure has similarities to optogenetics, a groundbreaking tool that allows scientists to turn neurons on and off with pulses of light.
But Chalasani says that sonogenetics has some advantages over this technique.

Unlike light, which needs to be sent through an optical fiber to the desired point in the brain, low-frequency ultrasound waves can pass through tissue without obstruction, and thus can be sent into the brain through the skull.

Chalasani said, "We believe that human neurons targeted for specific neurological therapies can be made temporarily sensitive to ultrasound signals by using gene therapy and a therapeutic virus in the clinical setting."
He adds that other applications can focus on muscle cells and insulin-producing cells.
Illegal torture equipment- Right on your doorstep!
Advertisements shame Britain's arms trade
Watch the International Peace Bureau's anti-weapons fair video.
Terrifying killer drones!
ankle-breaking shackles!
The songs are powerful bombs!
And tasers that can cause excruciating pain, yet leave no marks!

A subtle audio and animation created for the International Peace Bureau to highlight the UK government's desire to sell weapons to repressive regimes through the Defence and Security Equipment International exhibition at ExCel Centre in London Docks leaves no room for doubt that the world's largest arms fair is a cruel deception.
Related: DSEI arms fair: Authoritarian regimes attack in London
But a different campaign continues with posters on bus stops and on metro trains, requiring a second look.
One of them turns the DLR line into a tank by using London Underground fonts and branding, saying, "Important announcement: Will you be traveling on the DLR between the dates of 15-18 September?"
This September, a horde of arms dealers will attack DLR. The customers are asked to help stop this arms fair.
300 poster is a work of art by artists who exhibit their work in the Cruel Designs Museum in Banksy's Dismaland.

A collective called the Special Patrol Group distributed it by using "Ad Strike Packs", worth 6£, which they claim gives access to "approximately one third of all bus stop advertising spaces on the planet".
Transport for London was not happy with this "vandalism" of the poster.
One of the advertisements was created by the Special Guard group collective.

According to Gavin Grindon, the curator of Cruel Designs and a lecturer at Essex University, artists are becoming more and more inquisitive, and they are looking for ways to take their political works to audiences outside the galleries.
Many artists are taking part in the protest movement alongside activists, and they are realizing that they need to come out into the real world in order for their art to have an impact on society.
Another poster against arms trade appears in front of the people travelling on the metro.

The video by the international peace organization was watched over 100,000 times on Facebook in 24 hours and was created by the free-working VCCP advertising agency, and the graphic designer and the sound artist also prepared it without charge.

VCCP creative director Matt Lever was amazed at the silence around weapon fair advertising - there's a gap in the ExCel calendar - and thought: "let's offer them a campaign they'd want to run away from."
They played with the idea of making a more realistic and cunning corporate advertisement, but they "decorated it with bright colors and animation, which made it more eye catching."
Tom Davies from Amnesty International said "they have been very helpful in raising concerns about the sale of illegal torture equipment at the fair."
What we need now is for the UK government to take action and prevent the illegal sale of torture equipment on our doorstep.
Perhaps the most creative art at the arms fair comes from inside the ExCeL, where exhibitors are selling fantastically camouflaged products.
Saab revealed the order for the US Army's "shoulder-launched AT4CS RS" in a press release.
It contains "a warhead that is uniquely shaped and designed to penetrate the target's armor and inflict massive damage."
Whatever he is doing, it is not going to be good.
Eight golden rules for living in student dorms

It's been 11 years since I moved into student accommodation as a 19-year-old with an apathetic attitude, and I still believe in berets and moral relativism, but I now remember the artificial smiles of those I annoyed - and their numerous lengthy complaints about others.
Most of what I've learned can be distilled into eight golden rules.
Moving home could range from being nerve-racking to being utterly terrifying.

The charm of the chitchat: where you come from, if you have lost a year, where you have insisted on Corbyn and why you are like " Let's be honest, Marmite, I do not like or hate it because it is actually yeast extract HAHAHAH I'll be in my room."
Take a deep breath.
And let others do the same - ask questions and show interest.

This conversation will steer you in the right direction, and will help you separate people who you like from those who you would not want to talk to even if your eyelashes were on fire and they were holding a fire extinguisher.
Give people a little space.
The rooms often turn into venues for alcohol receptions, movie nights, and hangouts, but they are also where people get dressed and adjust their underwear.
Related: Don't even think about starting a university relationship
The introverts get bad treatment at the university.
Your room may be a place of retreat, but many dorms foster a culture of hanging out in the hallways, and it can be friendly, social, and great for making lifelong friends.
This can be hell for someone trying to store energy.

In the culture, there is nothing that permits you to say "I like you and I want our friendship to continue, but I need some space so that I can replace the energy I have spent in communicating with you."
Try to sense when a friend is getting weary of socializing and perhaps send a message instead of knocking on the door.
Speaking of knocking on a door: do it.
A friend in the dormitory had adopted a policy that if the door is not locked, you are invited to come in.
He has seen a lot of things.
Make friends through cooking.

At the zenith of the food contest craze, since you started college, it would be less weird and less 1950s "welcome to the neighborhood, I made you something, now smile as I ask you personal questions" to introduce yourself by knocking on people's doors with a plate of brownies.
Offering people home-made treats is a great way to make friends.
Roommates will feel compelled to talk and will perhaps associate your face with a sweet surprise.
To be honest, this is about you being a master chef.
A lumpy dough, sugar and fat that have not been properly mixed can cause people to pretend they are sleeping when you knock on the door.
Stealing food is a very common crime in student dormitories.
To be honest, stealing someone's chicken is a crime, but is it stealing to take a few drops of milk for your tea?
Check the milk owner twice.
He will very likely tell you to fend for yourself even when he is swimming in it.

It's very upsetting that someone's been stealing your things- and I can understand how you feel about it- but you must try to deal with it in a more mature way than my flatmate did. She put liquid soap in the milk to punish the thief.
He is in prison now.
Do not make noise that will prevent people from sleeping or studying.
It is not just about being a decent human being, but also because you are living in glass houses.
A girl in my corridor told her neighbour next door to turn the drums down a bit because it was 3 o'clock in the morning and she had an exam the next morning.
The answers to this question were to turn the volume up.
Finally, at 5 am, the girl turned off the music and locked the door, politely allowing them to sleep for two hours before she went to her own three-hour exam.
Wouldn't it be romantic if your future spouse moved into the same corridor with you?
Alternatively, wouldn't it be weird to misinterpret a corridor mate as a future spouse, to get together, break up, and then have to see them every day and watch your mutual friends be held hostage?
Of course, you are eager, but if your hot corridor neighbor is not your future spouse, you should at least chat with him/her and recommend common sense.

When you find out that someone has left their keys inside the house and locked the door in a moment of merriment, know that the line between a joke and being cruel to someone is thinner than you think.
A good joke is amusing, but it will take time to come back.
You can teach someone a valuable and amusing lesson about security by hiding their belongings, but never deface someone's room with shampoo and toothpaste.
Lock your doors and freeze your keys in a cup of water, but do not stick your belongings to the ceiling more than twice.

The woman, who had an injection of filler material in her face, subsequently had an increase in her heart rate and breathing rate.

The police is investigating whether the woman's daily use of a drug called "Potenay" had a role in her death.

The oil companies have officially collapsed

From the year 2014, when oil prices began to decline, to the end of last year, approximately $400 billion worth of investment was postponed while the most deep sea oil exploration projects were delayed.

According to a study by consultancy company Wood Mackenzie, low oil prices have caused a halt to $380 billion in oil and gas exploration/production projects, while millions of barrels of production have also been postponed across a wide geography, from the Mexican Gulf to Africa.

The report states that the biggest reason for cost reductions is that the oil prices, which were at 115 dollars in the summer of 2014, lost 70 percent of its value in one and a half years and fell to the lowest level in 12 years. The report also states, "Company budgets have been dramatically reduced."
400 billion dollars are at stake.
As crude oil prices continue to make new surprises every day, it recently fell below 30 dollars, reaching the lowest level in the last 12 years.

The research, published by energy consultancy Wood Mackenzie amid heated arguments on whether or not oil prices will fall to $15 and whether or not oil has become cheaper than water, reveals how the sector has been affected by the falling prices.

In a report published this July, Wood Mackenzie showed that falling oil prices had led to the postponement of $200 billion worth of 46 major energy investments. In its new research, the company reveals where this figure will stand by the end of 2015.
According to this, 22 major projects were postponed in the last six months of 2015, and a total of 68 major projects have been postponed since the decline in oil prices began in 2014.
The value of these projects is approximately 400 billion dollars.
2.9 MILLION BARRELS PER DAY
The report emphasizes that the effect of low oil prices on company plans is 'harsh', and points out that the most affected projects are deep sea development projects.
The projects that are put on hold correspond to a total of 27 billion barrels of oil equivalent reserves, and 2.9 million barrels of oil production per day is delayed until 2025.
According to the research, the final investment decisions for most of the projects have been postponed until 2017 or later and the first production targets have been delayed to between 2020 and 2023.
The report emphasized that among the 68 delayed projects, there are $170 billion worth of potential investment planned to be made within the next five years, “Most of it is deep-sea projects.”
One of the reasons for this is that the initial investment cost is very high.
It is said that 70% of deep-water spending is concentrated in Nigeria, Angola and US projects in the Gulf of Mexico.
According to the research, the countries with the highest inventory of delayed oil projects are Canada, Angola, Kazakhstan, Nigeria, Norway and the United States.
These six countries have almost 90 per cent of the world's proven oil reserves.
Mozambique, Australia, Malaysia and Indonesia, the countries with the largest amount of deferred gas reserves, together constitute 85% of the total.
While most of the natural gas waiting to be tapped here is located in deep water, complex and expensive development solutions such as building a liquefied natural gas (LNG) facility are required.

While it is pointed out that the companies most exposed to the risk are the deep sea, Canadian oil sands, and Caspian region oil giants, which have committed themselves to a series of commitments, it is also stated that the companies are trying to adapt to the "lower and longer" oil price scenario.
EYES ON IRAN

Not so long ago, the picture looked like this: The U.S. and Europe had imposed an embargo on Iranian oil in order to stop Tehran's nuclear program, the price of oil was around $110 a barrel and there was a discussion about how to cut Iranian oil exports without causing a sudden jump in prices.
When we return this week, we see a completely different scenario.
Oil prices fell below $30 for the first time since 2004, due primarily to a production boom in the U.S. and the lifting of sanctions against Iran.
For this reason, eyes are on Iran.
If Iran increases its oil exports, it will bring even more oil to a market that is said to be already saturated.
This could cause prices to fall below the levels that surprise us today.
Some analysts say that Saudi Arabia, which does not want to lose market share to Iran, may pump even more oil, which can lead to a price war between Iran and Saudi Arabia.
It is noted that once the sanctions are lifted, Iran's principal targets will be the rapidly growing oil market in Asia India and its former partners in Europe.
Iranian authorities had said in previous statements that they aimed to increase exports by 500 thousand barrels per day in the first stage and later release another amount to the market.
According to Reuters' map information, 22 very large crude oil carriers (VLCC) are waiting in the Persian Gulf, and at least 13 of them are completely or partly full.
Iran is the holder of the world's fourth largest proven oil reserves.
Thanks to the sanctions exceptions, Iran is still able to export approximately a million barrels of crude oil per day to some countries, including Turkey.
Before the sanctions, Iran's daily oil exports reached up to 3 million barrels a day.

Support Securities Research Expert Aysun Göksu answers the question of whether oil will go below 20 dollars as follows: "While concerns about global growth centered in China increase the downward pressure on commodity prices, they cause a deepening loss in oil prices."
We see that oil prices have dropped by 20% since the beginning of the year due to the concerns that the demand for oil will decrease as the Chinese economy slows down.
In addition, due to the fact that the dollar is gaining value globally and the effects of the global supply surplus problem, we will see crude oil being priced under 30 dollars in the upcoming days.
As long as we do not see permanent pricing above the $32-33 level, the upward movement in oil may be limited and downward pressure may increase.
At this point, it can be said that closing below the critical 30-dollar level has a key role in continuing the declines.
In this case, declines down to the support zone between 23.30 and 25.60 are not surprising.
Isham Sardouk: 'The angel era is over now!'
While you were performing the task of generating trends at Victoria's Secret and WGSN, which determine the fashion trends of the world, why did you turn your way to Turkey?
- I am always in favor of change.
I was born in Paris, lived in London and then went to New York.
I also held important positions there.
Meanwhile, I have been advising Koton for the past two years.
Then I saw the potential in this geography and in the Koton brand.
I realized that this store had everything necessary to be a world-class chain.
I am here now to make this happen.
Can you do this in a short time?
- Definitely.
Although it is already a young brand, it is already sold in 50 countries.
We produce 50 collections a year, and we have 15 different sections.
In other words, it has everything a chain of stores should have.
We can respond to the needs of consumers in different geographical locations, from Dubai to Moscow.
Now we are opening a store in Paris in March, which is the beginning of a new and exciting period...
Is it a requirement to open a store in Paris?
- Yes.
Not because Europe's economic situation is wonderful.
But you open some stores for the image.
You have a shop in fashion capitals like Paris and London and you earn money from the Middle East.
One adds prestige to the brand, the other adds money, and both are necessary for a brand playing for global reach.
Let's talk about trends...
- We have a very romantic, stylish season ahead of us.
Fluttering chiffon dresses, soft tones, pinks, whites and reds.
Patterns...

We are going through very difficult and ruthless times, and the fashion world always tries to bring cheerful and inspiring designs to the runway to add a little happiness to life during these tough times.
We do that too.
So for the new season, the “age of elegance” comes back.
Let's go back to your years in Victoria's Secret.
Who was the most legendary angel? - Karolina Kurkova.
I am not just talking about her amazing physique: she is such a positive, such a good girl!
While I was working, she would sit by my side and feed me with apple etc. saying "My dear, were you hungry?"
It was so sweet.
You know what I'm talking about, I researched and you've interviewed all the Victoria's Secret models.
Wasn't Karolina so beautiful?
But Adriana Lima also impressed me with her beauty.
- Yes, that voice!
That style of speech, that tone ...
After a while, it demeans you, and you think, "Just sit there and look beautiful, and don't do anything else."
It is nerve-racking.
Yes, such shocks do happen.
I had an interview with Candice Swanepoel.
She was the most beautiful girl I had ever seen, but I was horrified at her foolishness.
- Most of them are like that now.
The new angels are not like the old ones…
I remember the Gisele period...
Although it was a bit difficult to work with him.
He went backstage and smoked like a chimney.
It's not because he's a bit of a rogue.
No one else can drink, but he can drink!
The aim is to be a diva.
The Victoria's Secret fashion show, which aired two months ago, received the lowest rating in its history.
Why do you think so?
- As I said, the era of those legendary beautiful angels is over.
Who can do anything to Gigi Hadid?
What is nice is that?
For example, Kendall Jenner is as stiff as a board...
There are no bends, nothing.
Kate Moss has no curves, but she is one of the biggest names of the fashion industry.
- Yes, but her face was so beautiful.
I would like to exercise my right to object here.
Last year I interviewed him and he looked quite downcast...
- So much smoking, drinking, now it's become ugly, of course.
But in the nineties she had such a beautiful face.
Her lips were like Brigitte Bardot's.
She arrived at the end of the supermodel era.
The era of Linda Evangelista, Naomi Campbell, and Christy Turlington...
Christy was my neighbor and I saw her every morning without makeup.
There could not be such a dignified beauty and such a grace.
What about Cara Delevingne?
- He is ruining himself.
Not every campaign includes it.
People get bored.
There is no longer any hunger for famous models and celebrities.
People want to see real faces similar to themselves in campaigns.
We will also go on this.
Because it's the trend.

The new rights that are planned to be made available to women working in public service and as laborers after giving birth or adopting a child have been passed through the commission after hours of discussions.

Bagdadioğlu indicated that if temporary employment is revived, new problems will arise and he said, "We will follow the developments regarding private employment agencies with concern."
TİSK Secretary General Bülent Pirler indicated that the law introduced partial work for a period of 5 years, and said, "There is no partial work for such a long period in any other country."
Look at the issue this way.
"We should think about the effects of this practice in places that only have one or two employees," he said.
TOBB Advisor Ahmet Şağar also said that if the application is put into practice, there will be difficulties in finding workers.

Şağar says, "There is no legislation about the rules that will be applied in part-time employment. Regulations should be passed regarding private employment agencies, and an agreement should be reached between workers and employers."
Metin Feyzioğlu: We do not support it.

We are the bridge.

Who is Bergen?
Bergen, whose real name is Belgin Sarılmışer, was born on July 16, 1960 in Mersin.
Following his parents' divorce, he moved to Ankara with his mother, Sebahat Çakır, in 1966.
After graduating from Yunus Emre Primary School in Yenimahalle, he entered the Piano department at Ankara State Conservatory, but he left due to financial difficulties and worked for a while at PTT.
In 1979, he accepted an offer for work after he took the stage at Feyman Night Club, where he went to have fun with his friends.

Feyman performed at the Night Club Feyman with the Group Lokomotif orchestra, and presented a repertoire consisting of Turkish Art Songs, Turkish Light Music, and arrangements of popular songs of the era.
After going to Adana for business from Ankara, Bergen met Halis Serbes here and got married a year later.
In 1982, he released his first long-play album, "Şikâyetim Var", from Atlas Plak.
While her artistic career was on the rise, Bergen could not endure her husband's violence. She ran away from her husband many times.
In October, 1982, when she was working in Izmir, someone threw acid in her face by the instigation of her husband.

Bergen, who lost only one eye and had most of her body burned in the attack, was convinced by Cengiz Özşeker, the composer of the song "Kimbilir", which made Kibariye famous after the treatment, to get on stage.

The artist, who performed on stage at Izmir Diamond Pavilion, which was owned by Özşeker until 1985, prepared a demo cassette entitled "We Are Brothers of Destiny" with his boss and sent it to Yaşar Kekeva.
Kekeva, who liked Bergen, invited the artist to Istanbul.
The artist, who released "İnsan Severse", the first professional longplay in the İstanbul music market, under the music direction of Burhan Bayar, became famous in late 1986 with "Acıların Kadını".
The album was widely appreciated, and the record label honored her with the "1986 Best-Selling Arabesque Female Singer" award with Golden Record and Golden Cassette in April 1987.
In the same year, he shared the screen with Yalçın Gülhan, Asuman Arsan and Meral Niron in the movie "Acıların Kadını", the script and direction of which was done by Ülkü Erakalın.
Bergen, who has a large fan base, narrowly escaped from a knife attack in Adana, where he went for a concert.

After a period in which he left the stage, the artist released his albums, "Onu da Yak Tanrım", "Sevgimin Bedeli", and "İstemiyorum" with the direction of great masters Selami Şahin, Özer Şenay, and Cengiz Tekin, respectively.
In April 1989, Bergen was officially divorced from her husband, and in June 1989 she returned to the stage with her final album in her lifetime, "Years Do Not Forgive".
The singer, who began the promotional tours of his album, which received a lot of interest, was shot dead by his ex-wife in Pozantı, Adana, on the night of August 14-15, 1989.
He was buried in his hometown of Mersin.
In his short life, which lasted only 29 years, Bergen managed to fit in five long plays and eleven cassettes, with 129 songs and a video film.
Claims that the artist had become a legend with his unique and powerful voice were substantiated by the fact that the album released after his death was sold out on the first day.
Bergen's officially released studio albums:
1982 - I Have a Complaint LP (re-released as MC in 1986)
1983 - Kardeşiz Kader LP (Reissued on MC in 1985 and 1990.)
1985 - İnsan Severse LP, MC (re-released in 1999 as a CD)
1986 - The Woman of Pains LP, MC (re-released on CD in 1999)
1987 - Onu da Yak Tanrım LP, MC (re-released in CD format in 1999)
1988 - The Price of My Love (re-issued on CD in 1999)
1988 - I Don't Want LP, MC (re-released on CD in 1999)
1989 - Yıllar Affetmez (Originally the last album) MC (Re-released in 1999 as a CD.)
1990 - My Youth MC (reissued on CD in 1999.)
1990 - The Suffering of the Poor Ends in the Grave MC (Re-released on CD in 1999.)
1991 - My Last Tear MC, CD
Nazım Hikmet was commemorated on his 114th birthday
Nazım Hikmet Ran, who is known as the poet of the country, was commemorated with the event "I am glad you were born, Nazım" on the 114th anniversary of his birth.
The event, organized by the Konak Municipality, was held in the hall named after the poet in the Güzelyalı Cultural Center.
The event included poetry and music performances, and the famous poems of the poet were read by the theater and movie actor Rüştü Asyalı.
Also at the event, Three Anatolian Music Groups accompanied Asyalı with their interpretations.
Many art lovers attended the Nazım Hikmet event.
Among these names are Ali Seçkiner Alıcı, Erkoç Torun, Nedim Yıldız, Zeynep Göknur Yıldız and Ziya Özsökmenler.
In Istanbul, an event was organized by the Nazım Hikmet Culture and Art Foundation.
The Foundation President Rutkay Aziz and members, Nâzım Hikmet's wife Vera Tulyakova's daughter, son-in-law, and grandson, actor Tarık Akan gathered in Tarabya for the event.
They will read poems with the slogan "To live like a tree, alone and free, like a forest, in brotherhood," and leave carnations on the sea.
The event, organized with the contribution from Sarıyer Municipality, will be accompanied by songs from Nâzım Hikmet Choir.
Nazım Hikmet was born on January 15th, 1902.
The poems of the world famous poet Nazım Hikmet have been translated into more than 50 languages.
He was arrested numerous times for his political beliefs, and he spent most of his adult life in prison or exile.
His poems have been translated into more than 60 languages, and his works have won many awards.
He died on June 3, 1963.
Bursa's Nilüfer Municipality conducted special projects for the 114th birth anniversary of the world-famous poet Nazım Hikmet.
The municipality, which is working on the documentary "Bursa's Nazım" that tells the story of Nazım's 11 years in Bursa Prison, also issued a personalized coin for the first time in Turkish history.
Thus, with the cooperation of the PTT, the first personal postage stamp in Turkey bearing the name of Nazım Hikmet was issued.

The special stamp and the first day envelope are priced at 1.40 TL and will be given as gifts to the guests at the event that will be held at the Nazım Hikmet Cultural Center on Thursday, January 14th.

It is a small thing done to my child in the presence of God and his Prophet.
Kurdi, who lives in Erbil, issued this call: "My call to the whole world and to the humor magazine is for everybody to show respect for all the children who have died."
They should not upset their families, should not add to their grief.
Tima Kurdi, the aunt of Aylan Kurdi who lives in Canada was also one of those who expressed their reaction to the cartoon.

In the cartoon signed by Laurent 'Riss' Sourisseau, there is an implication that when he grew up, three-year-old Syrian Aylan Kurdi, whose lifeless body washed up on the shores of Bodrum, could be one of the sexual harassers in Germany.

The French satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo, which was attacked last year by radical Islamists after publishing the cartoons of Prophet Muhammad, has been the focus of controversy again for a cartoon about Aylan Kurdi.

In the cartoon, women were shown being chased by pig-faced sexual harassers who resembled migrants, just like the sexual attacks on women in Germany, especially in Cologne, during New Year celebrations.
The cartoon, which triggered different reactions on social media, is actually a part of a four-panel column.
The column reads "This is not France" and it criticizes the increasing anti-refugee sentiment along with other French values that are said to have been lost.
On the other hand, the cartoon has led many people to accuse Charlie Hebdo of racism.
In an issue published last year, Charlie Hebdo also praised Germany for accepting 800 thousand refugees, while criticizing France for its reluctance to open its doors to migrants.
While the cartoon says "It was very close to its goal", the advertisement poster says "Two kids' menus for the price of one."
